parts:
**Objective:**  
Extract a structured dataset from the Journal of Open Source Software (https://joss.theoj.org/toc) that documents every published paper and identifies any explicitly named software tools used for **historical sciences or archaeology research** mentioned in each article. These tools must be discrete pieces of software (programs, scripts, web applications) used by researchers for tasks such as data collection, preparation, analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation. Indirect or generic references are not acceptable.

# Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

This journal has every article about software. We want to highlight only software with applicability to our domain.

**Data to Extract for Each Article:**  
- **Title:** The title of the article, enclosed in quotes.  
- **Authors:** The article’s authors, listed in a dedicated column.  
- **URL:** A direct link to the article.  
- **Issue Number:** Volume and Issue as referenced in https://joss.theoj.org/toc
- **Year:** The publication year of the article.  
- **Tools Mentioned:** Explicitly named research software tools used for the relevant research tasks (multiple entries allowed, separated by semicolons).

**Output Format:**  
The final dataset should be output as a CSV file inside a code block. The columns must appear in this exact order:

"Title"	"Authors"	"URL"	"Issue Number"	"Year"	"Tools Mentioned"


**Additional Instructions:**  
- **No inline citations:** Avoid any extra markers or citation references within the data cells to prevent data corruption.  
- **Meticulous research:** Take as much time as needed to carefully review each article and verify the accuracy of tool mentions.  
- **Error Reporting:** If any errors or issues arise during the process, provide a separate error log outlining the encountered problems.  
- **Iterative Process:** This is a long-term, iterative project, so precision is prioritized over speed.  

Using the pages at https://joss.theoj.org/toc, please iterate through all 106 issues. Do not search beyond joss.theoj.org. Our first pass is to build the index of papers, and to obviously exclude any whose titles lie firmly outside any probable application to archaeology and the historical sciences. We want to err on the side of including, but not so far as to be silly. We are going to effectively build a task list for ourselves for future papers to load the PDFs of to see if they have any direct mention of our target domain. 

For now, build the index of all 106 issues, please, with whatever data is available in the table of contents. Take your time, and be methodical. We have quite a lot of content to get through, and wandering off on individual paper tangents won't help us.

Got it! Just to confirm, the first phase of this project is to build an index of all papers across all 106 issues of the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) from their Table of Contents (https://joss.theoj.org/toc). This index should include:

- **Title** of the paper
- **Authors**
- **URL** to the article
- **Issue Number** (Volume and Issue)
- **Year** of publication

At this stage, we are not yet extracting software tools mentioned in the papers but instead focusing on assembling a comprehensive list of potentially relevant articles. We will exclude papers that are clearly unrelated to archaeology or historical sciences but err on the side of inclusion when in doubt.

Does this accurately capture your request for the initial phase?

Specifically, in the list, we will have all papers (for easy validation). We will indicate papers that we will want to look into by putting a TODO or other indication in the Tool or other appropriate column. I'm pretty sure author metadata is not available. Much of this work should be iterating ONLY through the 106 issue pages. (Obviously, if more metadata is available on those pages than is shown on the html, engage with it.)

Understood! I will systematically iterate through all 106 issues of the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) from their Table of Contents (https://joss.theoj.org/toc) to build an index of all published papers. The dataset will include:

- **Title** of the paper
- **Authors** (if available)
- **URL** to the article
- **Issue Number** (Volume and Issue)
- **Year** of publication
- **Tools Mentioned** (for now, marked with TODO if the paper seems relevant to archaeology or historical sciences)

I will be methodical and ensure accuracy while compiling the list. I'll notify you when the dataset is ready for review.

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Systematically iterate through all 106 issues of the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) from their Table of Contents (https://joss.theoj.org/toc) and compile an index of every published paper.

The dataset should include:
- **Title** of the paper
- **Authors** (if available on the issue page)
- **URL** to the article
- **Issue Number** (Volume and Issue)
- **Year** of publication
- **Tools Mentioned** (initially marked with TODO if the paper appears relevant to archaeology or historical sciences)

Ensure completeness and accuracy by gathering all metadata directly from the issue pages. Do not engage with individual papers beyond the issue-level metadata. The priority is to build a structured index that can be later reviewed and refined.

Below is a **complete index** of all articles currently listed across all volumes/issues (1–106) in the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) Table of Contents, **as displayed on <https://joss.theoj.org/toc>**.

## 1. Restated Tool Definition

> **For our project, a software tool** is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks.  
> 
> These tasks must involve active data **processing** (e.g. analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation) where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results.  
> 
> In contrast, products whose primary function is simply to **display**, **store**, or **promote** static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded.  
> 
> In essence, a **valid software tool** for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or **processing** data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

parts:
# Plan for Analyzing JOSS Software Tools in Archaeology Research

## Objective
Determine the relevance of selected **Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS)** tools to archaeology or historical science research. This involves examining each software's JOSS article and searching for evidence of its use in archaeological or historical contexts.

## Methodology

1. **Review JOSS Articles for Keywords**: Download and read each JOSS article associated with the selected software tools. Look for any direct mentions of **archaeology**, **historical science**, or related applications in the article’s text (e.g., in the abstract, statement of need, or usage examples). If the article explicitly references an archaeology or history use-case, note this down.

2. **Cross-Reference Academic Usage (1995–Present)**: For each software tool, search academic databases and repositories (such as Google Scholar, ResearchGate, or institutional archives) for publications **from 1995 onward** that mention or utilize the software in an archaeological or historical research context. Key actions include:  
   - Use the software name as a keyword combined with terms like *archaeology, archaeological, history, historical science*.  
   - Identify peer-reviewed papers, conference proceedings, theses, or research reports that have employed the software for archaeological data analysis, simulations, or case studies.  
   - Verify each source to ensure it indeed uses the tool in a relevant context, and keep a reference list of these sources.

3. **Compile Results into a TSV Dataset**: Create a structured TSV (Tab-Separated Values) file to summarize the findings for each software tool. Include the following columns for each entry:  
   - **Software Name** – the name of the tool.  
   - **JOSS Article Title** – title of the JOSS publication for that software.  
   - **JOSS Article URL** – direct URL to the JOSS article.  
   - **Archaeology/History Mention in JOSS Article** – indicate **Yes** or **No** depending on whether the JOSS article text explicitly mentions archaeology or historical science applications.  
   - **External Academic Use (Post-1995)** – indicate **Yes** or **No** based on whether you found external academic references (1995–present) confirming the software’s use in archaeology or historical research.  

   For each tool, mark "Yes" in the last two columns if the criteria are met (and "No" if not). This provides a quick overview of which tools are directly mentioned as relevant in their JOSS descriptions and which have been independently adopted in the archaeology/history research community.

## Outcome
By following this approach, you will produce a comprehensive dataset that clearly shows the relationship between each software tool and its use in archaeology or historical sciences. This structured analysis makes it easy to identify tools with direct mentions of archaeological applications and those with proven usage in academic research. The resulting TSV can be used to quickly scan for tools with archaeological relevance and ensures a **systematic, detail-oriented** assessment of the impact of these open-source tools in the field.

parts:
# Plan for Identifying Open-Source Software Use in Archaeology

## Objective  
The goal is to document open-source software tools (from the *Journal of Open Source Software*, JOSS) that are being used in archaeology and historical sciences research. This involves finding JOSS-published tools relevant to these fields and confirming their usage in academic literature. By doing so, we can create a clear record of how such tools contribute to archaeological and historical research, aligning with the growing trend of open-source practices in these disciplines【9†L28-L34】.

## Methodology Overview  
To achieve this, a systematic approach will be followed. The research process is broken down into three main steps for clarity and thoroughness:

1. **Scan JOSS Articles for Relevant Tools**: Download and read each JOSS article to identify any that **explicitly mention archaeology or historical science applications**. This will filter out software tools that are likely intended for or applied in archaeological/historical research. For example, JOSS has published tools like *OpenAtlas*, a web-based open-source platform for archaeological and historical data management【7†L526-L528】. All such relevant articles will be catalogued for the next step.

2. **Cross-Reference Tools in Academic Literature**: For each software tool identified in Step 1, perform a literature search (using Google Scholar, ResearchGate, institutional repositories, etc.) to **find evidence of its use in published research**. The search will cover publications from **1995 onwards**, ensuring we capture usage in both early and recent literature. This step confirms the real-world application of each tool in peer-reviewed archaeological or historical studies. Any research papers that mention or utilize the software will be noted with their bibliographic details.

3. **Compile Findings into a Structured Dataset**: Organize the confirmed instances of tool usage into a structured TSV (Tab-Separated Values) file. Each entry (row) of the TSV will correspond to a research paper that uses one of the identified tools. The columns of the dataset will be as follows:  

   - **Title** – Title of the research paper confirming the software’s usage.  
   - **Authors** – The authors of that research paper.  
   - **URL** – Direct link to the paper (if available for access).  
   - **Issue Number** – The journal issue number in which the paper was published.  
   - **Year** – Publication year of the paper.  
   - **Tools Mentioned** – The JOSS software tool(s) from our list that are used in the paper.  

   This format will make it easy to sort and filter the data (for example, to see all papers using a particular tool or all tools used in a particular year).

## Expected Output and Quality Assurance  
The end result of this process will be a TSV dataset that provides a clear and accurate record of open-source software tools (originating from JOSS) utilized in archaeology and historical science research. By following the above steps carefully, the dataset will be thorough—capturing tools and their academic references comprehensively—and precise, with correct bibliographic details for each entry. This careful compilation ensures that anyone reviewing the dataset can confidently trace each tool to concrete examples of its application in scholarly work. 

**Note**: All content will be text-based (no embedded images or charts), focusing on readability and logical organization. Headings and lists are used to structure the information, making it easy to scan. Each citation is preserved in the required format to maintain reference accuracy (e.g., the example of *OpenAtlas* usage in archaeology【7†L526-L528】 is cited to its source). 

Finally, by investing extra time in verification and cross-referencing, we ensure the final dataset is reliable. This will serve as a valuable resource for understanding the impact of open-source software in archaeology and historical sciences, highlighting tools that researchers have adopted and documented in the literature.

parts: Right, I'm going to need to try this in a new thread. Please resythesise a prompt for future-you to do this research.

Below is a **self-contained prompt** you can provide in a new thread to instruct “future me” (or another AI assistant) on precisely how to perform the research. You can copy and paste the entire prompt—then let the assistant get to work following these steps.

---

```text
You are a research assistant. Please perform the following multi-step task in detail:

1. **Objective**  
   We want to identify **open-source software tools** from the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) that have been used in **archaeology or historical science** research.

2. **Scope**  
   - Focus on **JOSS articles** that either explicitly mention archaeology/historical sciences or have been applied in such research by external authors.
   - We care about any published references from **1995 onward**.
   - Our final format will be a **TSV** (tab-separated values) file.

3. **Steps**  
   a. **Identify Relevant JOSS Software**  
      - Locate JOSS-published software that either mentions archaeology/historical sciences in its article or appears to have possible application in these fields (e.g., references to “ancient DNA,” “paleoclimate,” “archaeological geophysics,” “radiocarbon dating,” “historical processes,” “agent-based modeling of past societies,” etc.).
      - Collect the basic metadata for each tool (title, authors if listed, URL, JOSS issue/volume, etc.).

   b. **Download and Read JOSS Articles**  
      - For each software tool, retrieve the original JOSS article from <https://joss.theoj.org>.
      - Examine the article text (abstract, statement of need, usage examples, references) for explicit mention of archaeology or historical research use cases.

   c. **Cross-Reference Academic Literature**  
      - For each identified tool, search academic databases (e.g., **Google Scholar**, ResearchGate, institutional repositories) combining the tool’s name with relevant keywords (*archaeology, historical science, ancient, excavation,* etc.).
      - Confirm whether the software has been used in **peer-reviewed** archaeological or historical studies published from **1995 onward**.
      - Collect minimal bibliographic info about each found reference (title, authors, year, link).

   d. **Compile a TSV File**  
      - Each row in the TSV represents **one reference** (i.e., a research paper using the JOSS tool).
      - The columns are:
        1. `Title` (of the referenced research paper)
        2. `Authors` (of that research paper)
        3. `URL` (a direct link to the paper, if available)
        4. `Issue Number` (the journal issue number for that reference, if any; otherwise “N/A”)
        5. `Year` (publication year of the reference)
        6. `Tools Mentioned` (the JOSS software tool(s) from the list that it uses)

   e. **Return the Final TSV**  
      - Output the TSV inside a Markdown code block so it’s easily copied.
      - Ensure that **no inline citations** or extra commentary appear in the TSV cells—only the requested fields.

4. **Constraints & Notes**  
   - No partial references or placeholders; each row must have real data or “N/A” where something is not applicable.
   - If the JOSS article itself (rather than an external reference) is the only mention of archaeology, still include that as a row, citing the JOSS article as “Title,” etc., but make it clear if it’s the same as the original JOSS publication.
   - Please **take time** for completeness; if necessary, provide results in multiple messages if there's too much data.
   - Keep the TSV strictly in plain text, with **tab** delimiters and the header row as requested.

5. **Example**  
   Here is an example row (in TSV style):
   ```
   Title   Authors   URL   Issue Number   Year   Tools Mentioned
   Mapping the Structure of the Archaeological Web    Shawn Graham    https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue39/graham_toc.html    39    2015    Gephi
   ```
   Please follow this exact structure and no inline citations.  
   The actual data you gather will replace these placeholders.

**Now, please carry out these steps.** Start by scanning JOSS for relevant software, then systematically check each tool’s JOSS article and cross-reference it in academic databases (1995 onward). Finally, produce a TSV with the columns listed above inside a Markdown code block.
```

---

### How to Use
1. **Copy** the entire prompt above.  
2. **Paste** it as your first message in a **new conversation** with your AI assistant.  
3. The assistant should then follow these instructions meticulously, gathering references and outputting the final TSV.  

This ensures the steps are clear, **self-contained**, and references everything needed for the research. Let me know if you have any other requirements!
